section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Alphabet Cards (Aa, Bb), The Attic, The Bath, drawing and writing supplies

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read Clifford’s Manners. The book was filled with words and letters.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Aa Alphabet Cards Show the Alphabet Cards for the letters Aa. Say the letter aloud and have children repeat it. This is uppercase A. The letter A makes the /a/ sound you hear in the word apple. This is lowercase a. The letter a makes the /a/ sound you hear in ant.

Teach Bb Alphabet Cards Show the Alphabet Cards for the letters Bb. Say the letter aloud and have children repeat it. This is uppercase B. The letter B makes the /b/ sound you hear in the word bike. This is lowercase b. The letter b makes the /b/ sound you hear in bear.
Teach Share The Attic. Today we will read about the letter Aa. Then we will read a book about the letter Bb.
Read Read aloud The Attic and use the following prompt.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Tap your nose when you hear a word that begins with the /a/ sound.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Read Read aloud The Bath and use the following prompt.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Tap your ear when you hear a word that begins with the /b/ sound.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model Model writing uppercase and lowercase letters Aa and Bb. Provide drawing and writing supplies. Guide children in practicing forming their letters.

As you read The Attic, stop at each word that begins with or has the letter Aa. Have children say /a/ and the word. Repeat with The Bath and the letter Bb. Some children will benefit from tracing letters in trays of salt or sand.

For a challenge, after reading each story, ask children to try to recall all the words that begin with the target sound and letter. Then invite children to name any other words they know that begin with that letter and sound.

Before doing the activity, do a picture walk through the book. Read the words and help children locate the object being named. Then say the name of the object and have children repeat it. This will help them when they listen for the target sound at the beginning of a word and in the medial position. Note that the letter a in Spanish is pronounced “ah,” not /a/.
Children who struggle to maintain attention may need reminders about the sound they are listening for. Before reading each page, remind children what sound they are listening for.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Colorful cupcake liners, paper fasteners, scraps (fabric, yarn, felt) glue, craft sticks, one completed flower

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read Clifford’s Manners. We saw how Clifford used good manners everywhere he went. We saw that Clifford really cared about others.
Remind children that they talked about empathy and ways to make someone who was upset feel better.
Share with children that for this activity they will create happy flowers to share with someone who is not feeling well, is upset, is feeling sad, or needs cheering up.
Set out the materials that children can use. Show the flower you made and point out that you decorated it and then added the pop stick for the stem.
Invite children to use the materials to make their own happy flowers. Suggest children begin with decorating the cupcake liner which will be the petals of the flower and then adding the stem.
As children work, talk with them about who they might want to give their happy flower to and why. Remind them of some of the reasons a person might be sad, upset, or need cheering up.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Talk About Making Someone Feel Better Remind children they can say to friend, “Are you okay?” to find out if someone is sad or upset. Have pairs model asking and answering that question. Guide children to see that sometimes a smile, a pat on the head, helping out, or a happy flower can make someone feel better.

If children need help telling who they might want to give the flower to, name children in the class or a family member. Encourage the child to say when and why he would give the flower to that person.

Ask children to tell about a time when someone they know was sick and had to stay in bed. Invite them to make a Get Well card to save for when they need it. Help children write the words Get Well on the card and talk about ways to make it cheerful.

Invite multilingual learners to teach the other children how to say, “Are you okay?” in their home language. Take the opportunity to have English speaking children learn the expression and take turns saying it for the group.

Children who have difficulty with activities that involve using fine motor skills may need help with creating the flowers. It might be helpful for you to attach the cupcake liners to make the basic flower and then have children just decorate the flowers. Help children by holding down flat the flower petals, so children can glue small scraps of fabric, yarn or felt.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials poster board, markers, sticky notes

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we reread Clifford’s Manners. It’s important for friends to have good manners, even when they disagree. Today we’re going to talk about a fair way to make a decision.
In this activity, each of you will vote for a class activity. You will have three choices but can vote for only one of them.
First, let’s talk about what it means to vote and how it can help friends have good manners when making decisions.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted: When you vote, everyone gets to say what their choice is.
After everyone votes, the votes for each choice are counted.
The choice that has the most votes is the activity we will all do.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Present Choices We have lots of friends in our class. Taking a vote is a fair way to make a decision. Today we’ll vote for the activity we want to do together. Present the three choices. Write them along the bottom of the chart. Give each child one sticky note and have them line up. One at a time, place your sticky note on the chart, above the game you want to play. Everyone will get a vote.
Tally Votes Count the number of sticky notes above the first activity. Write the total. Repeat. Announce the winner.

Talk About It Explain to children that if their choice wasn’t the one that most friends wanted, they will have other opportunities to play their game. Invite children to share how they feel about the outcome of the vote. Explain that it’s okay to be disappointed, but they need to have good manners and be polite.

Draw a simple image (or paste a picture) of each activity below its name to assist children in interpreting the chart. Talk through each choice with children when it’s their turn to place their vote on the chart.

Challenge children to determine which activity got the fewest votes and which activity came in second. Assist with counting again to emphasize where the count stops in each column. Have children repeat the number with you as you point to the written number.

Small-group learning has been shown to be beneficial to multilingual learners. Consider seating arrangements before beginning the lesson. Some multilingual learners feel more confident about participating in conversations when seated directly beside the teacher. Others find encouragement through eye contact. Sit these learners across the table from you and make a conscious effort to make frequent eye contact.
When it’s the child’s turn to vote, make sure she can see your face clearly and hear your instructions. Repeat the instructions for voting, and ask the child to repeat back to you what is expected.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Construction paper, art supplies

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read Thank You, Friend! on the Big Chart. We learned about different ways to be a good friend.
First, let’s talk about what we learned about how to be a good friend.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted: Talk about ways to be a good friend.
Write children’s responses on chart paper. Possible responses include take turns, share, listen, and so on.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today, we are going to make thank-you notes.

ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted.ac_teacher-speaking: Think of a time when someone did something for you. Write a note to that person thanking them for their good manners.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model Share a thank-you note that you made ahead of time.
Guide As you watch the children in the creative process, ask them about their note.

ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted.ac_teacher-speaking: Who are you writing to? What are you thanking them for?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Talk About It Invite children who want to share their thank-you notes with the class. Sometimes thank-you notes are very private between people. This means they don’t like to share it with anyone else. Please touch your nose if you would like to share your thank-you note. As children share, ask them how their friend showed good manners, and ask them when they have shown good manners to their friends.

If children cannot remember a time to write about, ask them if they can remember a time someone in the class has shown good manners. Then, ask them look at the chart the class made to get ideas. Have them write about one of the ideas.
Encourage children to write or draw about a time when they could have practiced good manners, but didn’t. What did you do instead of being polite? How did that make you feel?

As multilingual learners work, allow them to use words from their native language interspersed with English. The important thing is that they feel encouraged to freely participate in peer conversations. You might even find that some English speakers start to learn words and phrases from multilingual learners’ home languages.
Children with fine motor challenges may find working with a partner helpful. Together, they can discuss how their friends practice good manners and how they can do the same.
